docs.lead_paragraph: The Origins and Evolution of the Moonbean Name | Jesse McKinley explores the history of a nickname for Jerry Brown, which was given to him in 1976 by Mike Royko, the syndicated Chicago columnist who later asked that people stop using it. With Mr. Brown announcing last week that he would seek to become California's next governor, the "Governor Moonbean" sobriquet was resurrected by some as a description of someone who is unpredictable. Mr. Brown, who is the state's attorney general, said the name, to him, symbolized other qualities, like being "creative and not hidebound to the status quo." He added: "Moonbeam also stands for not being the insider, but standing apart and marching to my own drummer. And I've done that." [The New York Times]

docs.abstract: Pandora, the Internet radio station which has spent most of its 10 years on the verge of death, struggling to find investors, is now attracting attention from investment bankers who think it could go public, the pinnacle of success for a start-up, The New York Times writes.
